title_sort: alfred pratt and john b. pratt to walt whitman, 14 january 1870
title: Alfred Pratt and John B. Pratt to Walt Whitman, 14 January 1870
text: January 14, 1870Dear Walt WhitmanI received your vary[very] kind Letter and picture and am vary[very] glad to hear from you. I all so[also] Received your vary[very] kind Papers, and have taken great pains to lay them away to look at some future time, but the book I have never seen.Well now I will tell you about my mother. She sits in her chair kniting[knitting] a pair of mitens[mittens]. She says that she has a great angsity[anxiety] to See you my father would like to see you also. My brother is enquiring I we could all meet you with a harty[hearty] welcome.Mother has a very bad cold at praisent[present], the rest of us are usaly[usually] well.I will send you one dollar to get some pictures with the picture you sent me of your self I take a good look at it every now and then. I thank you vary[very] much for the last one you sent, the views that you sent me are to be of the public buildings of the city. I expect to start for Kansas next Tuesday but my had to postpone it for a few days on the account of death in the familyIf you write soon I shall get itI expect tonight some friend here to make an evening call. You will pleas[please] excuse me from writing as I wish to have some room for my father as he said he would finish this. So fare the[thee] my Dear Walt do not forget to address Williamson, Wayne Co. NYMuchrespectedFriend W Whitman it is with the greatest pleasure I attempt to write a few lines to fill out Alfred's letter we all feel a good the warmest affection for you for you very great poems have conferred on us in writing to us when our son Alfred was sick among strangers and among strangers we have formed a great desire to see you and have a good and friendly talk. We did think that you would start out in the bad weather and get out of the city and see us but now my boy is a going to Kansis[Kansas] to live he expects to start for Kansas with some of our neighbours next Tuesday a week to settle perhaps you may think it not whorth[worth] a while to come and see us but we are very anxious to see you if you think you can posibly[possibly] come have here of 130 acres 3 horses two year old colts 9 cows and expect 4 more in the spring (that is 4 heifers come in on the next steer) (continued for want of room) and a lot of poltry[poultry] such as turkeys Ducks and chickensOh I had a daughter last augAugust a year ago and she lives with us yet but I expect to be able leave with her in a few days she ways[weighs] about 100 lbs and is as handsome as a picture I think I will have her picture before she goes and I will send you oneplease except[accept] our thanks for past favours.Mrs Pratt send you her respects in particularPlease write soon to your unworthy friendsJohn B. Pratt P.O. WilliamsonWayne Co,NY Walt WhitmanDear FriendI am now at my own home but have not got my discharge yet. I left Washington on trans furr[transfer] to rochester[Rochester].I have to go back to rochester[Rochester] to get my discharge.the day that I left thare[there] avent[I went] to the patent office to see you but you was[were] not thare[there], and I had not time to go whare[where] you was[were] but, avent[I went] back to ward C and gave to no C thare[there] in the ward 70 ctscents to give to you he said that he would let you have it the first time that you came in. Now pleas[please] rite[write] and let me know if you got it I wanted to see you I would like to no[know] if you got that money anyhow. I got two weeks ago last Friday, but I find myself rather weak yet last friday[Friday] I was on A lode[load] of hay and went to get down of[off] from it and I fell and scard[scared] the horses one them kicked me on the forehead then they start to run and the wagon wheel struck me on the back of my head and hurt me bad but can sit rite[right] now. I think of no more at preasent[present]. Pleas[Please] rite[write] if you get thisAddressAlfred E PrattAug the 7th WilliamsonWayne Co.N YMy friends their respects Pleas[Please] if get this rite[write] and if you will Pleas[Please] send me that photograph of abe[Abe] and Washington like yours if you can find them and I will Say I glad for it Alfred Pratt and John B. Pratt to Walt Whitman, 14 January 1870
